awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: Development of Polymeric Organosilica Membranes for Hydrogen Purification at 100 – 300 oC
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project is that the silica membrane products will enable low-cost production of hydrogen gas, (H2, a clean energy carrier), and carbon dioxide (CO2, a greenhouse gas) capture for utilization or storage on a large scale - economically mitigating CO2 emissions to the environment. Specifically, the  program will bring the technology beyond the laboratory by demonstrating scalability of membrane production using conventional processes and capitalizing on the long-term stability of the membranes when used with realistic gas streams. The team seeks to license the technology to a membrane manufacturer and developer, which can then conduct pilot-scale field tests of the membrane systems and offer small commercial systems for separation and purification of H2 from various industrial streams. The students participating in this program will benefit from interdisciplinary training on membranes and separation, H2 purification and carbon capture, materials science and engineering, and advanced manufacturing. The research will become a valuable vehicle to attract students from underrepresented groups at various levels (graduate, undergraduate, and high school) to experience entrepreneurial multi-disciplinary research and inspire them to pursue STEM careers and entrepreneurship.

The project aims to demonstrate the potential of polymeric organosilica (POSi) membranes by meeting three milestones. (1) Prepare membranes with 50% higher H2 permeance and three times higher H2/CO2 selectivity than current commercial membranes by optimizing polymer precursors and fabrication conditions; (2) Scale-up membrane production (10 – 100 m2 membrane area) using industrial roll-to-roll facilities; and (3) Demonstrate continuous long-term (2-4 weeks) performance and stability with simulated gas mixtures. The key innovation of the technology is a facile means of preparing an ultrathin layer (10 nm or less) of inorganic material on top of polymeric membranes, providing superior H2 permeance and H2/CO2 selectivity. Such polymeric membranes are routinely produced in industry, and they provide excellent mechanical support for the ultrathin inorganic selective layer during processing and use. the team's approach represents a new, scalable, reproducible, and low-cost means of preparing inorganic membranes for gas separation, in contrast to the high cost and poor scalability of existing production routes, which have prevented the adoption of high-performance inorganic membranes for gas separation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. We have developed a series of polymeric organosilica (POSi) membranes with superior H2/gas separation properties by oxygen plasma treatment of the polysiloxanes. We systematically investigated the influence of the fabrication parameters, including ICP power (Watt), RIE power (Watt), chamber pressure (mTorr), plasma exposure time (s), and oxygen gas flow rate (sccm) on the performance of the POSi membranes, aiming to improve pure- and mixed-gas separation properties. Importantly, we incorporated phenyl groups in POSi to improve hydrothermal stability and H2/CO2 separation properties in practical conditions. The derived structure/property relationships can guide the design of silica membranes for various gas separations. This study also demonstrates a facile, scalable way to fabricate ultrathin inorganic membranes on polymeric supports, which may stimulate interest in this new way of developing inorganic membranes.

 

Broader Impact. This project has provided training experience for four PhD students (Vinh Bui, Ameya Tandel, Taliehsadat Alebrahim, and Narjes Esmaeili), three MS students (including Varun Satti, Shweta Singh, and Sai Srikar Chundury), and an undergraduate student (Elizabeth Haddad). Elizabeth became interested in materials and separations and joined Saudi Aramco, Boston, MA, in the summer of 2022. She also earned the travel award from the North American Membrane Society (NAMS) to attend the NAMS annual conference in Phoenix, AZ. All three MS students obtained their degrees, and Ms. Shweta Singh decided to join the PhD program in 2023.

 

The students also participated in the I-Corps program to explore the commercial potential. They completed the ICorps workshop, conducted technology surveys with more than 100 stakeholders, and gave various presentations. They investigated the demand and applicability of our membrane materials for industrial H2 purification and pre-combustion CO2 capture. They studied the strategic approaches of the membrane development companies to determine a profitable model for our potential business. Valuable entrepreneurship development for the students has been demonstrated.

 

Furthermore, the students worked closely with an industrial partner, which is one of the leading membrane manufacturers in the US. A materials testing agreement was signed, and several membranes were fabricated at UB and evaluated by the partner. The H2/CO2 separation performance is consistent with that obtained in our lab. After the validation, we started working on an agreement for both parties to work together. Such experience is valuable in shaping their understanding of industrial research and product development.

 

One patent application was filed, and another provisional patent application was filed. The developed membranes show promise in their scalability, low cost, and superior separation properties for hydrogen separations from gas mixtures containing CO2, CH4, and other hydrocarbons.


Last Modified: 06/17/2024
Modified by: Haiqing Lin
